experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I'll be honest—I'm pretty nervous about this, but I know I need to get better at, like, talking to people, especially if I want to get into a good grad school.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! First off, it’s totally normal to feel nervous—I admire you for taking steps to improve. Since you’re already low in social anxiety, that’s a great foundation! Try joining a club like Toastmasters or a CS study group to practice speaking in low-pressure settings. Grad schools love seeing initiative, so this will also boost your application. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Toastmasters sounds... really intense. I guess I could check if the CS department has a smaller study group first. I'm just worried about saying something stupid in front of people who might be my future classmates.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart approach—starting small is totally valid! CS study groups are great because everyone's focused on the material, not judging your speaking skills. Remember, even if you stumble, it shows you're engaged. Plus, your future classmates will appreciate someone who's putting in the effort. You're already on the right track!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess that makes sense. It's just hard to remember that people aren't judging when I'm the one who can't get my point across smoothly. But you're right, the study group is probably the safest place to start.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! And the more you practice in a supportive space, the more natural it'll feel. Everyone in those groups is there to learn—including from each other. You're building skills that will help in grad school interviews too. Keep taking those small steps; they add up!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess that makes sense. It's just hard to believe it'll ever feel natural when my mind goes blank in front of three people. But you're right about grad school interviews... I really need to get a handle on that.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that—even three people can feel huge! But think of it like coding: you debug small issues first. Every time you speak up, you're fixing a "bug" in your confidence. Grad school interviews are just bigger versions of these practice runs. You're already building the skills—trust the process!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good way to think about it, I guess. I just worry that when it's a real interview, the pressure will make all my code crash at once.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Great analogy! But remember—interviews aren't live coding without a net. You can prepare "error handling" by practicing common questions and having a few key points ready. Even if you freeze, a deep breath and a simple "Let me gather my thoughts" shows maturity. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's true... I guess I just worry that even with preparation, my mind will go blank when I professor is staring at me. But having a simple phrase ready does sound safer.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Even seasoned speakers have go-to phrases for when they need a moment. It shows self-awareness, not weakness. Try practicing with a friend staring at you—it'll feel less intense when it's real. You're preparing smart, not just hard. That's what will set you apart.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could ask my roommate to stare at me, but he already does that when I'm trying to study. It just feels so awkward, even in practice.
